newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan plans to renegotiate CEPA power deal.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan plans to renegotiate CEPA power deal.

text.p: Pakistan plans to re-negotiate its agreement with Consolidated Electric Power Asia (CEPA) to set up a power plant and develop a sea port, a government official said on Friday.

The official, who asked not be named, said Pakistan had decided to re-negotiate the deal with CEPA, which was struck in June 1995 when Islamabad issued a Letter of Support, enabling the power company to complete other formalities. Hopewell Holdings Ltd holds a 20-percent stake in Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd, U.S power giant Southern Co owns 80 percent.
Under the agreement CEPA was to build eight 660-megawatt coal-based thermal power plants for a total cost of $5.5 billion in the southern province of Sindh.

The official said the Economic Coordination Committee of the cabinet decided on Thursday to set up a committee headed by the secretary to the Ministry of Water and Power to re-negotiate the Letter of Support with CEPA.
"We are not just saying no to them," the official said. Asked about the fate of the project he said: "It depends on the outcome of the negotiations."
CEPA officials in Pakistan could not be immediately reached for comment.

CEPA had plans to develop a 14-metre deep sea port at Keti Bundar, about 60 km (37 miles) west of the port city of Karachi in Sindh and also set up a special industrial zone at the site with a total cost of $1.0 billion.
The port was to be developed in three years and ships with a cargo handling capacity of 70,000 tonnes could berth at the 14 jetties planned to be built.

Hopewell chairman Gordon Wu signed a memorandum of understanding with the government of ousted prime minister Benazir Bhutto in October 1994 to build the coal-fired power stations, set up transmission lines, build roads and dedicated rail links to the Thar coal reserves.
